block.p: Katharine Rix Markham, the daughter of Stephanie Reed Hastings of Fryeburg, Me., and the late James M. Markham, was married yesterday in North Conway, N.H., to Andrew Kerr Piper, a son of Ann and Thomas L. Piper III of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Jack H. Haney officiated at Christ Church Episcopal, with the Rev. Richard Fabian, an Episcopal priest and the bride's godfather, taking part.

The bride, 28, and the bridegroom, 27, graduated from the Groton School, where they met, and from Princeton University. They now attend Columbia University, where she is a candidate for master's degrees in social work and public health and he is studying for a doctorate in German literature.

Katharine Rix Markham, the daughter of Stephanie Reed Hastings of Fryeburg, Me., and the late James M. Markham, was married yesterday in North Conway, N.H., to Andrew Kerr Piper, a son of Ann and Thomas L. Piper III of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Jack H. Haney officiated at Christ Church Episcopal, with the Rev. Richard Fabian, an Episcopal priest and the bride's godfather, taking part.

The bride, 28, and the bridegroom, 27, graduated from the Groton School, where they met, and from Princeton University. They now attend Columbia University, where she is a candidate for master's degrees in social work and public health and he is studying for a doctorate in German literature.

The bride, who is known as Tinka, is to become an intern next month at the Multiple Sclerosis Society in New York. Her mother, a photographer, operates Hausfrau Foto, a greeting-card business in Fryeburg. Her father was a correspondent for The New York Times and its bureau chief in Saigon, Beirut, Madrid, Bonn and Paris. Her stepfather, Peter G. Hastings, is a partner in the Hastings Law Office in Fryeburg.

The bridegroom was a Fulbright scholar at Humboldt University in Berlin in 1996 and 1997. His father is a managing director in private banking at Citibank in New York; until January, he was a managing director for investment banking at UBS Warburg in New York.
